III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care.
Section (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
Description receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health care
provided shall be documented in the youth’s record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The foster care worker has failed to obtain insulin or follow
through with medical care for a diabetic youth.
Investigation On 5/16/23 DCWL received an intake stating that Youth A did not
have access to insulin, as Foster Care Worker did not fill the
prescription and provide it to her. Foster Care Worker was
provided with two phone numbers to pediatric endocrinologists to
make an appointment for Youth A to obtain insulin. Five days after
the phone numbers were provided, Complainant spoke with
Foster Care Worker and determined an appointment had not been
scheduled. Complainant then spoke with Youth A and spoke with
her about scheduling an appointment with the endocrinologist.
Youth A stated she had a prescription, but Foster Care Worker
had not picked it up yet.
DHHS Worker was interviewed by phone on 5/17/23. DHHS
Worker stated this complaint was filed with DHHS on 5/8/23; their
investigation was complete and without findings. Youth A is
pregnant and diabetic. Youth A currently has the insulin she
needs, although she may stay at the hospital until delivery, as it
was determined she was not managing her diabetes effectively.
DHHS Worker indicated the complainant may not have been
aware that Youth A already had her insulin prescription filled, prior
to making the complaint. DHHS Worker explained there was a mix
up about a month prior when Youth A was discharged from the
hospital for another medical issue. Youth A was given
prescriptions for prenatal vitamins, insulin, a glucose meter, and
test strips. Foster Care Worker was unable to take Youth A to pick
up these items due to an emergency with another youth on her
2

caseload. Someone else took Youth A to the pharmacy, where the
vitamins and insulin were filled. However, the pharmacy did not
have the glucose meter or strips. The prescriptions were returned
to Youth A and she was instructed to get the items from a medical
supply company. This information was not relayed to Foster Care
Worker. Therefore, Foster Care Worker was unaware Youth A did
not receive these items.
Complainant was contacted by phone and email on 5/17/23.
Complainant responded on 5/18/23 and provided identifying
information for Youth A. A follow-up email occurred with
Complainant on 6/7/23 in which they stated they were aware
Youth A had insulin. The complainant was concerned Youth A did
not have a glucometer. Complainant stated she was aware Youth
A would be staying in the hospital and her diabetes was under
control. However, she filed the complaint as she believed she was
making a complaint against Foster Care Worker’s social work
license. It appeared Complainant did not intend to file a complaint
regarding the agency’s license.
Chief Administrator was contacted by phone and email on
5/18/23. CA was informed of the investigation and allegation. On
5/19/23 CA provided contact information for Program Manager,
Foster Care Supervisor and Foster Care Worker.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed by video
conference on 5/30/23. FCW reported that until the complaint
came in, she was unaware that Youth A was not taking her insulin.
FCW stated that during monthly visits she would ask Youth A if
she needed anything or needed help with managing diabetes.
Youth A would respond no and indicate she had her medication.
When Youth A found out she was pregnant, her blood work
showed elevated sugar levels. Youth A told FCW that she did not
have insulin. FCW immediately scheduled an appointment with an
endocrinologist and obstetrician where she was prescribed
prenatal vitamins and insulin. FCW believed Youth A was taking
both medications from that point on. However, Youth A’s blood
sugar was very high recently and she was admitted to the
hospital, where she will remain until the baby is delivered. FCW
reported that she asked Youth A why she was not taking her
insulin as needed and Youth A did not have an explanation. FCW
stated that Youth A is in independent living and able to fill her own
prescriptions. FCW reported that after discharge from the hospital,
the agency hopes to have Youth A living in a Mommy & Me
program, as it appears she is not able to properly care for herself
in independent living.
3

Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed by video
conference on 6/8/23. FCS reported she became aware that
Youth A was not taking her insulin on the day DHHS began their
investigation. FCS stated that she knew Youth A had insulin, as
FCW had dropped it off at her apartment two weeks prior to the
complaint. However, Youth A was not administering it. FCS
reported going to Youth A’s apartment with DHHS on the day their
investigation started. FCS observed multiple bottles of unopened
insulin at the apartment. It was unknown why Youth A was not
using the insulin. It was noted that the insulin was not stored
properly. FCS and DHHS both spent time educating Youth A on
proper storage and administration. FCS also noticed some unfilled
prescriptions at Youth A’s house. FCS filled the prescriptions and
dropped them back off with Youth A that day, ensuring they were
stored correctly. Regarding the glucometer, Youth A had one
while living with her sister, prior to independent living. It is
unknown when Youth A lost the device as she did not tell FCS or
FCW that she needed help getting a new one. FCS spoke with the
medical supply company, which stated insurance will only replace
the device every five years. Therefore, the agency has ordered
one online and will be paying out of pocket for it. The device will
be provided to Youth A when she is discharged from the hospital.
FCS reported she did not have any concerns about Foster Care
Worker or her management of this case. FCS stated that Youth A
has struggled to do things for herself. Foster Care Worker has
been very supportive and went out to see Youth A every week to
assist her with obtaining food stamps, managing money, buying
groceries, and addressing school absences. Youth A received
daily transportation to school but would frequently refuse to go.
This information was all documented on a behavior plan in
MiSACWIS. FCS stated that Youth A also signed a medication
agreement, to acknowledge that she understood it was her
responsibility to manager her insulin. FCS indicated that due to
Youth A struggling in Independent Living, they are currently
looking for a mother/baby program for her.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 6/9/23. Youth A
reported having her glucometer while living at her sister’s home.
However, it was lost, or left at her sister’s home. Therefore, Youth
A did not have a glucometer for several months. Youth A reported
she did not have difficulty obtaining insulin. But the insulin could
not be taken if she did not test her blood sugar with the
glucometer. Youth A recalled being at the hospital a few months
ago for another health issue. When she was discharged, she
received a prescription for a glucometer, test strips and insulin. An
4

unknown person, not Foster Care Worker, took her to the
pharmacy and dropped the prescriptions off. When she picked
them up, they only had one bottle of insulin in stock and did not
have the glucometer, or strips. Youth A received the prescription
paperwork back from the pharmacy but did not take it anywhere
else to be filled. Youth A stated she also did not have needles to
administer the insulin. Youth A indicated she was waiting for the
agency to bring all of these items to her. When asked if she
requested these items from Foster Care Worker, Youth A said no.
Youth A did not identify any barriers to filling the prescriptions
herself, other than stating she did not want to take public
transportation. When asked if she needed more support that
independent living offered, Youth A stated no, she did not need
more support.
Documents reviewed
• DHHS report dated 6/7/23 indicated no findings.
• Youth A’s case record was reviewed in MiSACWIS.
Information relevant to this investigation is as follows:
o IL placement began on 8/12/22
o Medication agreement 8/16/22. “By signing below,
you are agreeing that you understand the statement
above and agree to administer the medication to
yourself, following directions provided by the
physician.”
o Emergency Room visit 3/23/23 confirmed
pregnancy. Lab work completed.
o Home visits documented monthly as required. Noted
Youth A prescribed insulin.
o 3/23/23 Beaumont ER- summary. Positive for
pregnancy, lab work completed. No mention of
diabetes concerns.
o Youth A did not attend four medical appointments in
March and April. Youth A did not inform Foster Care
Worker.
o 5/8/23 home visit noted “Youth was in the hospital
for a few hours they gave her ultrasound to see how
the baby was doing. Checked her blood levels and
Vitals. Youth was released and was transported
back home by hospital transportation afterwards.”
o 5/9/23 Safety plan- youth agreed to keep worker
informed of all appointments dates/times/locations.
Agreed to take all prescription medications. Attend
all medical appointments. Inform worker and
supervisor of any issues with appointments.
5

Transportation by (agency) to all appointments.
Worker will text (Youth A) at least weekly to see if
there are any concerns. (Youth A) will send pic proof
of attending appointments, attending school, and 3
meals a day.
Analysis Based on interviews completed and documents reviewed, Youth A
had access to insulin. There was insufficient information to
determine when the agency became aware of the youth’s need for
a new glucometer. However, Youth A reported that she previously
had one, lost it, and knew she needed one. Youth A stated she
would not use public transportation to obtain it. As Youth A is in
Independent Living and responsible for her own medication and
medical devices, no violation is found.
Technical Assistance:
The agency was advised to document that medication has been
viewed at every home visit with IL youth. In addition, the agency
was advised to document attempts to help youth obtain medical
devices if the youth is struggling to obtain it on their own.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
